headline: Poll: McCormick Leads Dr. Oz by 9 Points in Pennsylvania Republican Senate Primary
author: Jordan Dixon-Hamilton
sentences: “McCormick has a lead and he’s running well across the state, but the main feature of the contest right now is that Republican voters have not yet honed in on the candidates,” said Daron Shaw, a Fox News pollster.
The poll surveyed 960 Pennsylvania Republican primary voters from March 2-6 under the joint direction of Republican research firm Beacon Research and Democrat firm Shaw & Company Research.
Businessman David McCormick is the frontrunner in Pennsylvania’s Republican U.S. Senate primary, leading celebrity doctor Mehmet Oz by nine points, according to a recent Fox News poll.
For example, only 22 percent of McCormick supporters are certain they will cast their ballot for him, compared to 40 percent of Oz supporters confident in their support.
The poll found small support for candidates Kathy Bernette, Jeff Bartos, and Carla Sands, who received nine, nine, and six percent support, respectively.
The poll also asked voters about their policy priorities when choosing their senate candidate, and economic and immigration issues topped the list.
Close to one-third of voters remain undecided about which candidate to support in the Republican U.S. Senate primary set to occur on May 17.
Behind McCormick is Oz, who trails McCormick by nine points, earning just 15 percent support from Republican primary voters.
A recent TargetPoint survey found McCormick ahead of Oz by thirty points in a head-to-head battle.
Although McCormick leads Oz, Oz’s supporters feel stronger about him than McCormick’s supporters.
Nearly 60 percent of primary voters say the economy is “extremely” important to their decision.
McCormick is running to replace retiring Republican Senator Pat Toomey (R-PA) in Congress.
Other issues on primary voters’ minds are social issues and coronavirus health policies.
McCormick has the most support among Republican primary voters, at 24 percent.
Fox News’s poll is not the only poll that shows McCormick ahead of Oz.
Immigration was at the forefront of 53 percent of voters’ minds.
The poll has a margin of error of +/- 3 percent.
